Accipiter

Yesterday, Republican presidential hopeful and tea party favorite Michele Bachmann kicked off her campaign in her hometown of Waterloo, Iowa, where she told Fox News, "What I want them (voters) to know is just like John Wayne was from Waterloo, Iowa, that's the kind of spirit that I have, too." Except Wayne--the late actor known for Westerns like "Stagecoach," "The Searchers," and "True Grit," as well as for his conservative political views--was born in Winterset, Iowa, a three-hour drive southwest of Waterloo. Another John Wayne was born in Waterloo, but that was John Wayne Gacy, the serial killer. Gacy was locked up for a year in Waterloo for an attempted sexual assault before committing 33 murders in Illinois, for which he was executed in 1994. The name mix-up has made "Michele Bachmann," "John Wayne," and "John Wayne Gacy" spike in Yahoo! Search. Wayne, who is already a popular search term, was looked up nearly twice as much as usual yesterday, whereas searches for Gacy jumped almost 1,200 percent. See a graphic comparison of the two search spikes on clues.yahoo.com.

 
 Asteroid Buzzes Through Twitter, Michele Bachmann?s Mix-Up, and Twitter Sides With Supreme Court on Video Games | Trending Now - Yahoo! News

She has what spirit...the spirit of a guy from Waterloo that really isn't from Waterloo? Who gives a flying frogs green XXX where John Wayne or Bachmann are from? What in the hell does her incorrectly perceived commonality with an actor have to do with her ability to be president?
 
 2. She obviously either doesn't know a few basic facts about her hometown, and/or was simply parroting the words of some staffer that can't do basic research. Either way, not very confidence inspiring.
 
 Can't we get a serious candiddate that can think for themselves, perhaps write a few of their own speeches, and maybe even sound intelligent for a change? Ron Paul comes to mind...but not very many others.

 Anytime I have ever heard something a politician said and thought that both they really meant it and that it was correct they were quickly run out of the running. There is only room for empty platitudes because the idea that holding to any position with conviction (I don't mean any set of talking points I mean a real position, which you can define exactly and which has real and specific implications to your policy) is seen as 'idealistic' (a bad thing?), naive, ineffective (oh look they actually believe something they can't win), radical etc...
 
 Hence unless the culture changes we will keep electing obama and obama clones for the right. They will say things which no one can disagree, not because they are so profoundly true there are no opponents but because they say nothing at all and manage to distill the statement 'Things will be good' into other phrases.
 
 When they are elected they will sit and take the blame or credit for what ever the other branches of government do but never for what they do. They will do essentially one of two things, sit there and try to fight against progressing collectivism or try to advance it. In waves the advancers get control and so inch closer to their ideal.
 
 It won't get better, something must change.
